content: The Act may be cited as the "Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008". Congress finds that justice is served when all parties to litigation have experienced counsel, protecting attorney-client privileged communications promotes compliance with the law, and clarity on the privilege enhances organizations' compliance programs. Prosecutors and government officials can conduct their work while respecting these protections. The Department of Justice and other agencies have implemented policies that undermine the adversarial system of justice by encouraging organizations to waive attorney-client privilege and work product protections to avoid sanctions, despite the availability of investigative tools that do not impact the attorney-client relationship. Congress recognized this issue when it banned demands for privileged materials in the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The Department of Justice and other agencies have implemented policies that undermine the adversarial system of justice by encouraging organizations to waive attorney-client privilege and work product protections to avoid sanctions. An indictment can have devastating consequences on an organization, potentially eliminating its ability to survive post-indictment or dispute charges at trial. Waiver demands and related policies are encroaching on the constitutional rights and legal protections of employees. The purpose of this Act is to address these issues. The purpose of this Act is to establish clear limits to protect attorney-client privilege and work product doctrine, ensuring they are not used to conceal wrongdoing or evade the law. SEC. 3. Disclosure of attorney-client privilege or advancement of counsel fees as elements of cooperation. Section 3014 of Chapter 201 of title 18, United States Code, defines attorney-client privilege and attorney work product in the context of investigations involving organizations. The term 'organization' excludes a continuing criminal enterprise. The attorney-client privilege and attorney work product protections in federal investigations or enforcement matters prohibit agents or attorneys from demanding an organization or its employees waive these protections. The term 'organization' excludes criminal enterprises, groups seeking money through illegal acts, and terrorist organizations. In any federal investigation or civil enforcement matter, agents or attorneys of the United States are prohibited from demanding, rewarding, or penalizing an organization or its employees for waiving the attorney-client privilege or attorney work product protections. In federal investigations or enforcement matters, agents or attorneys cannot consider conduct related to charging decisions for organizations or their employees who refuse to waive attorney-client privilege or work product protections. In federal investigations or enforcement matters, agents or attorneys cannot consider conduct related to charging decisions for organizations or their employees who refuse to waive attorney-client privilege or work product protections. This includes asserting attorney-client privilege, providing legal counsel or financial support for employees, and having joint defense agreements between organizations and employees. In federal investigations, agents cannot consider conduct related to charging decisions for organizations or employees who refuse to waive attorney-client privilege. This includes joint defense agreements between organizations and employees. In federal investigations, agents are prohibited from demanding organizations or employees to refrain from exercising personal constitutional rights or legal protections in response to government requests. This includes not sanctioning employees for such decisions.
